title: History of the World's Tallest Man-Made Structures
subtitle: A chronological list of the tallest land-supported man-made structures throughout history.

data.name_and_location: Göbekli Tepe, Turkey
data.notes: Possibly one of the earliest known temples.

data.name_and_location: Tower of Jericho, West Bank, Palestine
data.notes: One of the earliest ever stone monuments.

data.name_and_location: Anu ziggurat, Uruk, Iraq
Pyramid of Djoser, Saqqara, Egypt
data.notes: First Egyptian pyramid, formed of six stacked mastabas.

data.name_and_location: Meidum Pyramid, Egypt
data.notes: Shortly after completion Meidum Pyramid collapsed due to bad design/instability and is now 65 m (213 ft).

data.name_and_location: Bent Pyramid, Dashur, Egypt
data.notes: Angle of slope decreased during construction to avoid collapse.

data.name_and_location: Red Pyramid of Sneferu, Egypt
Great Pyramid of Giza in Egypt
Yongning Pagoda in Luoyang, China
data.notes: It was destroyed by a lightning strike in 534. Its exact height is unknown, and estimates range from 137 m (in which case the Great Pyramid of Giza would've kept the record) to 240 m.

data.name_and_location: Great Pyramid of Giza in Egypt
data.notes: See also 2570 BC - 516 and 516 - 534. By 1647, the Great Pyramid's height had decreased to 139 m (456 ft) after its top was removed.

data.name_and_location: Old St Paul's Cathedral in London, England
data.notes: The spire was destroyed by a lightning strike in 1561. Its height is disputed, for example by Christopher Wren (1632–1723), who suggested a height of 140 m (460 ft).

data.name_and_location: Lincoln Cathedral in England
data.notes: The central spire was destroyed in a storm in 1549. While the reputed height of 525 ft (160 m) is accepted by most sources, others consider it doubtful

data.name_and_location: St. Mary's Church in Stralsund, Germany
data.notes: See also resumption 1573–1647.

data.name_and_location: Beauvais Cathedral in France
data.notes: Spire collapsed in 1573; today, the church stands at a height of 67.2 metres (220.5 ft).

data.name_and_location: St. Mary's Church in Stralsund, Germany
data.notes: See also 1549–1569. The church tower's spire burnt down after a lightning strike in 1647. Today the tower has a dome and stands at a height of 104 m (341 ft).

data.name_and_location: Strasbourg Cathedral in France
data.notes: By 1647, the Pyramid of Khafre's height had decreased from 143.5 m (471 ft) to 136.4 m (448 ft) after its top was removed.

data.name_and_location: St. Nikolai in Hamburg, Germany
data.notes: The nave was demolished by aerial bombing during World War II; only the spire remains.

data.name_and_location: Cathédrale Notre Dame in Rouen, France
Cologne Cathedral in Germany
Washington Monument in Washington, D.C., United States
data.notes: The world's tallest all-stone structure, as well as the tallest obelisk-form structure.

data.name_and_location: Eiffel Tower in Paris, France
data.notes: The addition of a new telecommunications tower in 2022 brought the overall height to 330 m (1,083 ft).

data.name_and_location: Chrysler Building in New York City, United States
Empire State Building in New York City, United States
data.notes: First building with 100+ stories. The addition of a pinnacle and antennas later increased its overall height to 448.7 m (1,472 ft). This was subsequently lowered to 443.1 m (1,454 ft).

data.name_and_location: Griffin Television Tower Oklahoma (AKA KWTV Transmission Tower), Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, United States
KOBR-TV Tower, Caprock, New Mexico, United States
data.notes: Collapsed in 1960; rebuilt

data.name_and_location: WGME TV Tower, Raymond, Maine, United States
KFVS TV Mast, Cape Girardeau County, Missouri, United States
WTVM/WRBL-TV & WVRK-FM Tower, Cusseta, Georgia, United States
WIMZ-FM-Tower, Knoxville, Tennessee, United States
KVLY-TV mast, Blanchard, North Dakota, United States
data.notes: See also resumption 1991–1998 and 1998-2008.

data.name_and_location: Warsaw Radio Mast, Gąbin, Poland
data.notes: Mast radiator insulated against ground, collapsed in 1991

data.name_and_location: KVLY-TV mast, Blanchard, North Dakota, United States
KRDK-TV mast, Galesburg, North Dakota, United States
data.notes: Height includes the 1998 addition of a short flagpole, which was later removed.

data.name_and_location: KVLY-TV mast, Blanchard, North Dakota, United States
data.notes: See also 1963–1974 and 1991-1998. 75-foot analog antenna was removed from the top of the structure in 2018 in digital repack construction

data.name_and_location: Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates
